Title: An investigation of attention mechanisms in histopathology whole-slide-image analysis for regression objectives
Main_Objective: To investigate attention mechanisms for regression tasks (predicting gene expression) from Whole Slide Images (WSIs) rather than classification.
Datasets_Used: TCGA BRCA (721 patients), Clinseq (270 patients), ABiM. Focused on gene expression regression, unlike the classification focus of BreakHis/EFSANet.
Backbone_Architecture: ResNet18 pretrained on ImageNet used as the feature extractor for tiles.
Attention_Mechanisms: Attention-based Multiple Instance Learning (MIL) to aggregate tile features into slide-level representations, allowing varying contributions of tiles.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Not explicitly modeled via EDL, but analyzes attention weights as a proxy for relevance/confidence in contributing to the label.
Loss_Function_Optimizer: Mean Absolute Error (MAE) for regression; Adam optimizer.
Key_Performance_Metrics: Spearman correlation (0.35-0.38) between predicted and actual gene expression; Attention models showed slightly higher sensitivity to domain shift.
Reported_Limitations: Attention mechanisms showed poorer generalizability (domain shift) compared to simple mean pooling in regression settings.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Validates the use of attention to weight informative tiles, supporting EFSANet's strategy of using attention before pooling. Warns about domain shift risks which EFSANet's EDL helps mitigate.
Key_Quotes: Attention mechanisms... allow models to better capture the relationship between set and instance labels [when] relatively few images contribute.

Title: Histopathological image based breast cancer diagnosis using deep learning and bio inspired optimization
Main_Objective: To improve breast cancer multiclass classification using a hybrid model optimized by Hippopotamus Optimization Algorithm (HOA).
Datasets_Used: BreakHis (7,909 images) and BACH (400 images); directly comparable to EFSANet's target data domain.
Backbone_Architecture: DenseNet-41 (Feature Extractor) combined with AlexNet-GRU. Note: They refer to DenseNet-41, likely a custom variation or typo for DenseNet-121/161.
Attention_Mechanisms: Convolutional filters for preprocessing (blur, contour, edge enhance); GRU used to capture sequential/spatial dependencies.
Uncertainty_Quantification: No explicit uncertainty quantification (Standard Softmax classification).
Loss_Function_Optimizer: HOA (Hippopotamus Optimization Algorithm) used for hyperparameter tuning; Standard Cross-Entropy implied.
Key_Performance_Metrics: 99.60% Accuracy on BreakHis/BACH, outperforming ResNet50 and EfficientNet variants.
Reported_Limitations: High computational complexity due to hybrid architecture and optimization overhead; potential overfitting on small datasets.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Strongly validates the choice of DenseNet as a backbone for breast histopathology. EFSANet improves on this by replacing the complex GRU/HOA with a lighter Attention+EDL head.
Key_Quotes: DenseNet allows for feature reuse through dense connections... particularly useful in histopathological image analysis where capturing detailed patterns is crucial.

Title: Learning and predicting the unknown class using evidential deep learning
Main_Objective: To extend Evidential Deep Learning (EDL) to handle unknown classes (modified-EDL) without setting arbitrary uncertainty thresholds.
Datasets_Used: MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, EMNIST (Non-medical). However, the methodology is the exact foundation for EFSANet's loss function.
Backbone_Architecture: Simple CNNs (LeNet-style) for proof of concept.
Attention_Mechanisms: None specific; focus is on the output layer and loss function.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Core focus is EDL. Uses Dirichlet distributions to calculate belief masses and uncertainty (u = K/S). Introduces m-EDL to explicitly model unknown classes.
Loss_Function_Optimizer: EDL Loss (Sum of squares or Log-likelihood + KL Divergence regularization). Matches EFSANet's edl_loss_function.
Key_Performance_Metrics: m-EDL maintained high accuracy (approx 98%) on known classes while successfully identifying out-of-distribution samples.
Reported_Limitations: Requires defining K+1 classes for unknown handling; tested on simple datasets, performance on high-dimensional medical images (like histopathology) remains to be proven.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Provides the mathematical justification for EFSANet's EDL loss and uncertainty score calculation (u = K/S). Supports the move away from Softmax for trustworthy AI.
Key_Quotes: EDL explicitly expresses the uncertainty of the prediction category by combining subjective logic with a neural network.

Title: Multiclass classification of breast cancer histopathology images using multilevel features of deep convolutional neural network
Main_Objective: To classify breast cancer histopathology into 4 classes using an Xception-based model and evaluating stain normalization techniques.
Datasets_Used: Colsanitas (Private, 2,250 images); similar classes to BACH (Normal, Benign, In Situ, Invasive). 80/20 train/test split.
Backbone_Architecture: Xception (Extreme Inception) pretrained on ImageNet; features extracted from 6 intermediate layers.
Attention_Mechanisms: Multilevel feature extraction (concatenating features from different depths) + Global Average Pooling (GAP). No explicit attention module.
Uncertainty_Quantification: None. Relies on standard Softmax probabilities.
Key_Performance_Metrics: 98.00% Accuracy, 0.969 Kappa on original images. Stain normalization (Macenko) achieved 97.78%.
Reported_Limitations: Computational cost of deep ensembles; stain normalization did not significantly improve results over original data.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Competitor baseline. EFSANet's DenseNet+Attention aims to beat Xception's 98% by capturing frequency features that Xception misses. Supports using unnormalized images if model is robust.
Key_Quotes: ...stain normalization techniques offered competitive performance, [but] could not surpass the results of the original dataset.

Title: Uncertainty-informed deep learning models enable high-confidence predictions for digital histopathology
Main_Objective: To implement uncertainty quantification (UQ) to establish thresholds for high-confidence predictions in lung cancer histopathology.
Datasets_Used: TCGA (Lung), CPTAC, Mayo Clinic. Application is Lung, not Breast, but the UQ methodology is directly transferable.
Attention_Mechanisms: None specific to architecture; focus is on post-hoc uncertainty estimation.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Monte Carlo (MC) Dropout. Dropout enabled during inference to generate a distribution of predictions; variance = uncertainty.
Loss_Function_Optimizer: Standard training; UQ is applied via inference-time dropout.
Key_Performance_Metrics: High-confidence cohorts (filtered by uncertainty) achieved AUROC 0.98-1.0, significantly outperforming non-UQ models (0.96).
Reported_Limitations: Requires multiple forward passes (computational cost); abstaining from predictions (leaving slides diagnosis-free) might be clinically challenging.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Contrasts with EFSANet's EDL. MC Dropout is slower (multiple passes) vs EDL (single pass). However, validates the hypothesis that UQ-filtered predictions are more accurate.
Key_Quotes: Uncertainty estimates are consistent with biological expectations... and robust against domain shift.

Title: Addressing Deep Learning Model Calibration Using Evidential Neural Networks and Uncertainty-Aware Training
Main_Objective: To investigate improvements in model calibration using Evidential Neural Networks (ENNs) and uncertainty-aware training (UvAC) on medical imaging tasks.
Datasets_Used: MNIST (Digit classification) and PC-CMR (Cardiac MRI artefact detection); distinct from breast pathology but relevant for method.
Attention_Mechanisms: None explicitly mentioned; focus is on the loss function and evidential output layer.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Evidential Neural Networks (ENN) utilizing Dirichlet distributions to model belief masses and uncertainty (vacuity).
Loss_Function_Optimizer: UvAC loss (Accuracy vs Uncertainty) and ENN loss (MSE + KL divergence); Adam optimizer.
Key_Performance_Metrics: Accuracy and Adaptive Expected Calibration Error (AECE). ResNet18+ENN+UvAC improved calibration significantly on noisy data.
Reported_Limitations: Calibration suffers when tasks require higher model capacity; UvAC alone failed to improve calibration on complex PC-CMR data.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Foundational paper for the EDL implementation in EFSANetV2. It validates the use of evidential loss to handle dataset noise/uncertainty.
Key_Quotes: The only approach that improved calibration for both... was the combination of the ENN and UvAC uncertainty-aware training. (Supports EFSANet's use of EDL).

Title: Evaluating Deep Learning Models for Breast Cancer Classification: A Comparative Study
Main_Objective: To compare CNNs (ResNet, DenseNet, etc.) against Vision Transformers (ViT) for Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC) classification.
Datasets_Used: Kaggle Breast Histopathology Images (277,524 patches); Identical to EFSANetV2 dataset. 50x50 resolution.
Backbone_Architecture: ResNet-50, DenseNet-121, ResNeXt-50, EfficientNet, MobileNet, and ViT.
Attention_Mechanisms: Self-attention inherent in the Vision Transformer (ViT) architecture.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Standard Softmax probability; no explicit uncertainty/evidence modeling.
Key_Performance_Metrics: ViT: 94% Accuracy, 0.95 F1 (Non-IDC). DenseNet-121: 92% Accuracy. EFSANetV2 target >94%.
Reported_Limitations: CNNs (like DenseNet) showed lower precision/recall compared to attention-based ViT; computational intensity of Transformers.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Establishes DenseNet121 baseline (92%). EFSANetV2 adds attention to DenseNet to bridge the gap to ViT (94%) without full Transformer cost.
Key_Quotes: The ViT model... achieved the highest validation accuracy of 94%, outperforming conventional CNNs. (Justifies adding attention to CNNs).

Title: Breast Cancer Histopathology Classification using CBAM-EfficientNetV2 with Transfer Learning
Main_Objective: To enhance EfficientNetV2 with Convolutional Block Attention Modules (CBAM) for histopathology classification.
Datasets_Used: BreakHis (9,109 images, 40X-400X magnification). Smaller than Kaggle dataset used in EFSANetV2.
Attention_Mechanisms: CBAM (Convolutional Block Attention Module) combining Channel and Spatial attention.
Loss_Function_Optimizer: Categorical Cross-Entropy; Adam optimizer with Cosine Annealing and Warm Restarts.
Key_Performance_Metrics: 99.01% Accuracy on BreakHis 400X. High performance due to attention + transfer learning.
Reported_Limitations: Limited dataset size (BreakHis); heavy reliance on data augmentation to prevent overfitting.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Validates the Backbone + Hybrid Attention strategy. EFSANetV2 uses Edge-Frequency attention instead of CBAM to capture texture better.
Key_Quotes: Integrating Convolutional Block Attention Modules... enhance EfficientNetV2's ability to prioritize critical tissue regions. (Supports hybrid attention).

Title: Ensemble Deep Learning-Based Image Classification for Breast Cancer Subtype and Invasiveness Diagnosis
Main_Objective: To classify breast cancer invasiveness and subtypes using an ensemble of CNNs on WSI patches.
Datasets_Used: BACH (400 WSIs) and BreakHis. Patched high-res images.
Backbone_Architecture: Ensemble of VGG16, ResNet34, and ResNet50.
Attention_Mechanisms: None explicit; relies on the diversity of the ensemble members.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Implicitly reduced variance via ensemble averaging, but no explicit evidential metric.
Key_Performance_Metrics: 98.43% Average Validation Accuracy on BreakHis (Ensemble) vs 97.3% (ResNet50 alone).
Reported_Limitations: High computational cost of training/inferencing multiple models (Ensemble) vs single model.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: EFSANetV2 aims to achieve ensemble-level accuracy (>98%) using a single Agentic model with EDL, reducing compute costs.
Key_Quotes: Ensemble model... achieved robust predictions... mitigating their weaknesses. (EFSANetV2 uses EDL to achieve robustness in a single model).

Title: Deep learning approaches for breast cancer detection in histopathology images: A review
Main_Objective: Comprehensive review of state-of-the-art DL techniques for breast cancer histopathology.
Datasets_Used: Reviews BreakHis, BACH, Kaggle IDC, Camelyon16, TUPAC16.
Backbone_Architecture: Reviews CNNs (AlexNet, VGG, ResNet), RNNs, Autoencoders, and GANs.
Attention_Mechanisms: Highlights attention mechanisms as a key trend for focusing on critical regions (nuclei/mitosis).
Uncertainty_Quantification: Discusses interpretability challenges but notes a lack of uncertainty quantification in many existing studies.
Key_Performance_Metrics: Notes accuracies generally ranging from 85% to 99% depending on dataset and magnification.
Reported_Limitations: Annotated data scarcity, lack of model interpretability, and variability in staining.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Provides the problem statement: need for interpretable, robust models. EFSANetV2 addresses the interpretability gap via Uncertainty scores.
Key_Quotes: Deep learning models can be difficult to interpret... limiting its applicability in medical images. (Justifies EFSANet's uncertainty output).

Title: Mutual Evidential Deep Learning for Medical Image Segmentation
Main_Objective: To improve semi-supervised medical segmentation using Mutual Evidential Deep Learning (MEDL) to handle label noise.
Datasets_Used: LA, Pancreas-CT, ACDC (MRI/CT). Not histopathology, but methodologically relevant.
Attention_Mechanisms: Class-aware evidential fusion (CAEF) acts as an attention mask based on reliability.
Uncertainty_Quantification: Evidential Deep Learning (EDL) based on Dempster-Shafer theory; Belief masses and Uncertainty scores.
Loss_Function_Optimizer: Dice loss + Cross-Entropy + KL-free evidential loss; SGD optimizer.
Key_Performance_Metrics: State-of-the-art Dice scores on ACDC (90.95%) using only 20% labeled data.
Reported_Limitations: Complexity of fusing heterogeneous networks; applied to segmentation, not classification.
Comparison_to_EFSANetV2: Validates the mathematical framework of EDL used in EFSANetV2. Shows that uncertainty can filter noisy data effectively.
Key_Quotes: Offers a probabilistic framework for modeling aleatoric and epistemic uncertainties. (Supports the theoretical basis of EFSANet's loss function).
